awd_titl_txt: Learning-Based Fault-Tolerant Traffic Management Algorithms for Intelligent Transportation Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
This grant will support research on fault-tolerant intelligent transportation systems. Intelligent transportation systems have a strong potential for congestion mitigation and energy savings. However, such systems rely on a large number of sensors and communications devices deployed in complex environments. Therefore, these systems are prone to sensing faults (misreported, corrupted, or missing measurements), which can significantly compromise system efficiency. To address this challenge, this project will develop traffic management algorithms that detect and resolve sensing faults. Based on these algorithms, a paradigm of real-time, online fault-tolerant traffic management will be studied. This project will advance the knowledge about resiliency of intelligent transportation systems and provide ready-to-implement solutions. The solutions have the potential for mitigating the economic and environmental losses caused by sensing faults and improving cyber resilience of the traffic system. The expected results will provide hints on fault-tolerant design of other civil infrastructure systems as well. Graduate and undergraduate students from underrepresented groups will lead the research activities. Transportation agencies will be involved in discussion on concerns for actual deployment.

The research activities jointly consider fault detection and resilient control for intelligent transportation systems. The modeling will synthesize physical law-based and learning-based approaches. Consequently, the models can integrate real-time information and adjust themselves to non-stationary environments with minimal human intervention. The objective will be approached via two research and one validation tasks. First, online fault detection and correction algorithms will be developed. These algorithms check consistency between observations from correlated sensors and between the observed data and physical law-based models, which contain prior empirical knowledge of the spatio-temporal correlation of sensor observations. Second, learning-based approaches will be incorporated into classical traffic control methods to design adaptive traffic management algorithms. The approach will provide guaranteed resiliency against sensing faults. Finally, the algorithms will be validated in a realistic micro-simulation testbed of a road network in New York City under a variety of sensing fault scenarios.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Traffic management could be challenging, not just because of increasing travel demands but also due to unexpected events such as accidents. Fortunately, thanks to advances in sensing, communication and automation technologies, traffic managers or agencies are enabled to track real-time traffic condition and regulate congestion via conventional controllers (e.g. traffic signals) or innovative vehicle-to-vehicle/infrastructure (V2V/V2I) communications-based mechanisms (e.g. route guidance). However, the new technologies may raise systemic risks of exposure to cyber threats including unreliable sensor measurements and malicious hacker attacks. In addition, drivers’ compliance with novel traffic routing control could be questionable. These problems likely compromise management strategies developed in nominal conditions. This project aims at i) analyzing controlled traffic systems subject to the aforementioined disruptions, and ii) designing resilient or fault-tolerant traffic control policies capable of demonstrating acceptable performance in face of disruptions.

The project outcomes can be summarized from five aspects, namely  

1)       Performance analysis: theoretical tools that quantify traffic network performance, given exact knowledge of traffic models and disruptions.

2)       System identification: a learning-based identification approach that estimates parameters of traffic models, given traffic data possibly with missing values.

3)       State estimation: robust observers/filters that estimate traffic states, given traffic models and noisy traffic measurements.

4)       Control design: resilient control designs for i) commuting corridors, ii) traffic networks made up of parallel links, and iii) general traffic networks.

5)       Simulation evaluation: a micro-simulation testbed equipped with a module of vehicle-to-infrastructure communications.

The first aspect is about theoretical analysis of impacts of disruptions; it lays the foundations (e.g. stability conditions) for control design. Since in practice we do not have exact knowledge of traffic models or accurate state measurements, the second aspect on system identification and the third aspect on state estimation serve as prerequisites of the fourth aspect about designing state-feedback control policies. The last aspect focuses on evaluation in a micro-simulation environment. The following presents more details about our outcomes.

For performance analysis, we first investigated when driver non-compliance with routing instructions destabilizes two-parallel-link networks. We obtained the stability and instability conditions that can yield lower and upper boundaries of network throughput. Then, we considered single-origin-single-destination traffic networks subject to general disruptions. We derived stability criteria that yield lower bounds of network throughput. We also investigated another problem about how traffic management strategies benefit from connected vehicles (CVs). Specially, we also proposed a Bayesian optimization approach to determine the optimal market penetration rate of CVs when CV data is exploited by ramp metering.

Then, we proposed a new method that combines physics principles with machine learning to estimate daily traffic model parameters. By integrating physics knowledge directly into the machine learning model, we enable it to calibrate these parameters even in the absence of precise ground truth data. Once trained, our approach generates reliable parameter estimates based on traffic measurements.

Next, we designed two kinds of state estimators. The first one is about traffic density at mainline roads (e.g., freeway corridors). The second one yields estimated queue length at access roads (e.g., on-ramps). The traffic density estimator addresses the issue of mismodeling in which case the model parameters are inaccurate. Simulation shows that, in an environment of time-varying traffic flow parameters, the proposed method considerably outperforms the traditional ones. The queue length estimator resolves the problem that queue length cannot be directly measured by conventional sensors (e.g., induction loops). This is achieved by combining conventional sensors and emerging CV data. We showed that the designed observer has guaranteed long-term estimation accuracy.

For control design, we first considered traffic corridors subject to disruptions of stochastic road capacity. We proposed resilient localized and coordinated ramp metering algorithms. To address the computational costs of designing coordinated ramp metering, we also proposed partially coordinated ramp metering. Then we investigated parallel links in face of cyber disruptions including sensing faults and cyber-attacks. We formulated Markov decision processes and stochastic games to yield optimal routing policies. For general traffic networks, we first designed a set of novel control policies that only rely on traffic state observation and network topology, which is different from traditional approaches in addition to requiring accurate knowledge of model parameters. This attempts to address the issue of mismodeling due to disruptions. At the same time, we considered the second approach. We applied stochastic processes to model disruptions and showed two easy-to-implement control strategies with throughput guarantees under special conditions.

In the last part, we built a micro-simulation testbed based on a real-world stretch of Interstate 210 Eastbound in California, U.S. The simulation model was well-calibrated based on real data. This helps to evaluate traffic management in a more realistic manner. Specifically, we investigated how CV data-aided ramp metering is compromised by packet loss occurring in V2I communications. Our study demonstrated the necessity of securing traffic control in face of intense cyber disruptions.
